title: 108_hr1997
content: The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as Laci and Conner's Law, amends Title 18 of the United States Code to include a new chapter for the Protection of Unborn Children. This chapter aims to provide protection for unborn children. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as Laci and Conner's Law, establishes a separate offense for causing harm to a child in utero. The punishment for this offense is the same as if the injury or death had occurred to the unborn child's mother. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004, also known as Laci and Conner's Law, establishes a separate offense for causing harm to a child in utero. The offense does not require proof of knowledge or intent regarding the unborn child. If the person intentionally kills or attempts to kill the unborn child, they will be punished as if they had killed a human being under specific sections of the law. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 establishes a separate offense for causing harm to a child in utero. If a person intentionally kills or attempts to kill the unborn child, they will be punished under specific sections of the law, but the death penalty shall not be imposed for this offense. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 establishes separate offenses for causing harm to a child in utero under specific sections of the law, excluding the death penalty. The Unborn Victims of Violence Act of 2004 establishes separate offenses for causing harm to a child in utero, with consent implied by law for medical treatment of the pregnant woman or her unborn child. The term 'unborn child' refers to a member of the species homo sapiens at any stage of development in the womb. A new section is added to the Uniform Code of Military Justice to protect unborn children in cases of death or injury. Any person subject to the Uniform Code of Military Justice who causes the death or bodily injury to an unborn child during the commission of certain offenses will be guilty of a separate offense and punished accordingly. Proof of harm to the unborn child's mother is not required for this offense. The section specifies that prosecution is not permitted for conduct related to abortion with consent, medical treatment of the pregnant woman or unborn child, or for any woman with respect to her unborn child.
